channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Trump Lauds M.B.S. During White House Visit and Dismisses Khashoggi’s Killing
item.description: President Trump rejected a U.S. intelligence report finding that Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman had ordered the murder of a journalist.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:description: President Trump and Mohammed bin Salman, the crown prince and prime minister of Saudi Arabia, in the Oval Office on Tuesday.

item.title: Once a Pariah, Saudi Prince Resets U.S. Relations on His Own Terms
item.description: Seven years ago, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman couldn’t visit Washington. When he arrived at the White House on Tuesday, he got F-35s, the world’s fastest chips and the central role in the remaking of the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Mohammed bin Salman, the Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia, leaving the White House on Tuesday afternoon.

item.title: Here’s Who’s Attending Trump’s Dinner for the Saudi Crown Prince: Elon Musk, Cristiano Ronaldo and more.
item.description: The guests at President Trump’s dinner for Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia included prominent figures in sports and business.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Congress Overwhelmingly Approves Releasing Epstein Files
item.description: After a near-unanimous House vote, the Senate agreed to quickly clear the bill for President Trump’s signature.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: As soon as the resolution passed, Democrats, among them Teresa Leger Fernandez of New Mexico, center, turned and applauded the House gallery where survivors of Jeffrey Epstein, the convicted sex offender, were seated.

item.title: Behind the Vote to Release the Epstein Files
item.description: The House approved a bill directing the Justice Department to release all files related to its investigation into Jeffrey Epstein, in a near-unanimous vote. Hours later, Senator Chuck Schumer won unanimous agreement for the Senate to pass the measure as soon as it arrived in the chamber.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni, Claire Hogan and James Surdam

item.title: Trump Berates Mary Bruce of ABC News After Question About Jamal Khashoggi
item.description: The president grew frustrated with Mary Bruce of ABC News over her questions during his meeting with the Saudi crown prince. On Friday, he told a Bloomberg News reporter, “Quiet, piggy.”
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum
item.media:description: Mary Bruce, the chief White House correspondent for ABC News, in the Oval Office on Tuesday.

item.title: For Trump, Epstein Is the Story That Won’t Go Away
item.description: President Trump is being held captive to a news cycle he can’t avoid or defeat when it comes to the convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump with Jeffrey Epstein in New York City in 1997.

item.title: Harvard Opens New Investigation Into Summers and Epstein
item.description: The university is reviewing newly released emails between convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein and former Harvard President Lawrence H. Summers, among other people at the institution.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: David Degner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lawrence H. Summers, the former president of Harvard, said he was stepping away from public commitments.

item.title: Trump Said to Authorize C.I.A. Plans for Covert Action in Venezuela
item.description: The president has signed off on possible operations inside Venezuela but has also reopened back-channel communications with the government of President Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The next phase of the Trump administration’s escalating pressure campaign on the government of President Nicolás Maduro could be sabotage or some sort of cyber, psychological or information operations.

item.title: Ecuador Votes ‘No’ to Hosting U.S. Military Base
item.description: A vote on Sunday rejected the expansion of a foreign military presence. It came as the U.S. military’s campaign in waters near Latin America has been roiling the region.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and José María León Cabrera
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Celebrations after the results of a constitutional referendum in Guayaquil, Ecuador, on Sunday.

item.title: Europe’s Chip Dreams Confront Business Realities
item.description: European chipmakers need TSMC’s help to grow their own semiconductor supply chain, but the chip giant’s Taiwanese suppliers find Europe a tough place to do business.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin and Xinyun Wu
item.media:credit: Milan Bures for The New York Times
item.media:description: TSMC is teaming up with European chipmakers to build a factory near Dresden, Germany, as Europe’s need to make its own chips has grown more pressing.

item.title: In the A.I. Race, Chinese Talent Still Drives American Research
item.description: Although some Silicon Valley executives paint China as the enemy, Chinese brains continue to play a major role in U.S. research.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz and Eli Tan
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: New research shows just how important Chinese engineering talent still is to Silicon Valley companies.

item.title: A.I. Video Is Threatening Our Ability to Trust Documentaries
item.description: A combination of technological developments and market forces is undermining the trust between viewer and filmmaker. What’s at stake is history itself.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson
item.category: Roadrunner: A Film About Anthony Bourdain (Movie)
The Jinx: The Life and Deaths of Robert Durst (TV Program)

item.title: Federal Court Blocks Texas’ Republican-Friendly Congressional Map
item.description: The move dealt a blow to efforts by Texas Republicans and President Trump to flip Democratic seats in the state. Texas quickly filed a notice of appeal to the Supreme Court.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti and J. David Goodman
item.media:description: A voter looking in August at a proposed redistricting map that was approved by Texas lawmakers for the 2026 midterm elections.

item.title: Trump Ramps Up Redistricting Pressure on Indiana Republicans
item.description: After the State Senate said it would not take up a new map, President Trump said he would support primary challengers against Republicans who bucked him.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.media:description: Gov. Mike Braun of Indiana and other Republicans have argued that redistricting in Indiana was necessary to counter gerrymandering by Democrats in other states.

item.title: How TikTok Helped Meta Land an Antitrust Victory
item.description: Silicon Valley has increasingly pointed at rapid digital changes to blunt government efforts to rein in its power.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe and Steve Lohr
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Washington headquarters of the Federal Trade Commission, which sued Meta five years ago.

item.title: Meta’s Victory Opens the Way for Silicon Valley to Go Deal Shopping
item.description: To avoid regulatory scrutiny, big tech companies had steered clear of buying start-ups outright. Meta’s antitrust win may change that thinking.
item.dc:creator: Eli Tan, Mike Isaac and Erin Griffith
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg, Meta’s chief executive, in September. On Tuesday, a federal judge found Meta had not violated antitrust law by buying Instagram and WhatsApp when they were tiny start-ups.

item.title: ICE Frees Blind Migrant Who Was Detained for Days in Isolation
item.description: Carlos Anibal Chalco Chango, 40, was released on Monday from an upstate New York jail where he had been held without his cane. It was a surprising move by an agency that rarely frees detainees.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Weiser and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
item.media:description: After his arrest, Carlos Anibal Chalco Chango was initially placed in a cell at 26 Federal Plaza, the ICE offices in Lower Manhattan, where he was barred from using a text-to-audio app that could help him read legal documents.

item.title: How to Make Sense of Law Enforcement in the Streets
item.description: The variety of federal forces deployed to support President Trump’s mass deportation campaign and anticrime efforts continues to expand. Often, it can be difficult for the public to tell them apart, or to understand what powers each agency has.
item.dc:creator: Bora Erden, Claire Hogan, Laura Salaberry and Alexandra Ostasiewicz

item.title: Trump’s Border Czar Threatens More Immigrant Arrests in New York City
item.description: Thomas Homan said that additional federal agents would descend on the city if it did not help with President Trump’s deportation campaign.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ley and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
item.media:description: Thomas Homan, the Trump administration’s border czar, said that he was targeting New York City because of its so-called sanctuary policies.

item.title: How Trump Has Used ICE, the National Guard and Other Federal Forces Across the U.S.
item.description: Charlotte and Raleigh in North Carolina became the latest cities to see federal forces move in. Here’s a rundown of what’s going on in each place.
item.dc:creator: Billy Witz
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Border Patrol agents questioned Chicagoans about their immigration status on the southwest side of the city this month.

item.title: Federal Judge Orders Some Texas Schools to Remove Ten Commandment Posters
item.description: The judge sided with families of students who had argued that the displays infringed on their religious freedom.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Texas law requires school districts to display the Ten Commandments in a “conspicuous location” in each classroom.

item.title: Elon Musk Puts Trump Feud Behind Him and Tiptoes Back Into Politics
item.description: Having struck an uneasy truce with the president, Elon Musk is starting to make political appearances again, and his allies are planning a DOGE reunion party.
item.dc:creator: Theodore Schleifer
item.media:description: Elon Musk at Charlie Kirk’s memorial service in September. On Tuesday, he attended a formal dinner that President Trump held for Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Kamala Harris Hits Campaign Trail in Tennessee Special Election
item.description: On Tuesday, the former vice president made her first campaign appearance for another Democrat since leaving office.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:description: Former Vice President Kamala Harris arriving at a campaign event for State Representative Aftyn Behn on Tuesday in Nashville.

item.title: Eric Adams, Still the Mayor, Is Increasingly Out of Office
item.description: In the waning days of his term, Mayor Eric Adams is spending a significant portion of his time far from New York City.
item.dc:creator: Dana Rubinstein and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
item.category: Eric Adams Federal Corruption Case (24 CR 556)
item.media:credit: Adam Gray for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the midst of a four-day trip to Israel, Mayor Eric Adams announced that he would next head to Uzbekistan.

item.title: At $236 Million, Klimt Piece Is Second Most Expensive Painting Sold at Auction
item.description: At $236.4 million, a portrait by Gustav Klimt is the second most expensive painting at auction, while Maurizio Cattelan’s golden toilet drew $12.1 million.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small and Julia Halperin
item.media:description: Modern art history: The auctioneer at Sotheby’s, Oliver Barker, hammered down a final bid on a portrait of Elisabeth Lederer by Klimt.

item.title: Trump’s Trade War Showed That China Can Stand Up to America
item.description: His ill-conceived tariff war exposed U.S. vulnerabilities, strengthened China’s leverage and undermined America at a pivotal time.
item.dc:creator: Rush Doshi
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Mr.Nelson design; Photographs by Getty Images

item.title: On Republican Neo-Nazism, Hamas and Israel: An Epidemic of Moral Cowardice
item.description: People with extreme ideology don’t care anymore about hiding their excesses or their agendas. It’s all out there online or on YouTube.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman

item.title: Trump Administration Gives Three Mile Island Nuclear Project $1 Billion Loan
item.description: The Pennsylvania site, shorthand for the dangers of nuclear power after a 1979 meltdown, is set for revival under a deal to power Microsoft data centers.
item.dc:creator: Qasim Nauman
item.media:description: Constellation’s nuclear power plant, called the Crane Clean Energy Center, on Three Mile Island near Middletown, Pa. earlier this year.

item.title: Israeli Airstrike on Refugee Camp in Lebanon Kills at Least 13, Officials Say
item.description: It was one of the deadliest Israeli strikes on Lebanon since a cease-fire with Hezbollah went into effect about a year ago.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward and Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Members of the Lebanese Army gathered on Tuesday at the entrance of the Ain al-Hilweh refugee camp after an Israeli strike.

item.title: Smoking Weed Could Lead to Less Drinking, New Study Suggests
item.description: In a makeshift bar on a college campus, researchers studied how smoking cannabis affected alcohol consumption.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: N.Y. Doctor Accused of Desecration Can Be Sent to Japan, Court Rules
item.description: A federal appeals court ruled that Masahide Kanayama, a surgeon and practicing Christian, may be extradited to face charges of vandalism.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Weiser
item.media:credit: Graham Dickie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Japanese authorities said a shrine and temple were daubed with oil, and that they had traced the acts to Masahide Kanayama through surveillance footage.
